title: Movies Under the Stars: Twister (1996)
description:
Date: August 31, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film.

Just run for your life when a destructive force of nature comes howling straight toward you, destroying everything in its path--when you're running from a Twister. Academy Award winner Helen Hunt stars as Dr. Jo Thornton-Harding, who as a small girl watched her father sucked to his death from her family's storm cellar by a massive tornado. Now a storm chaser, a scientist who risks her life to study the dark side of nature by taking her data-transmitting instruments directly into the path of a deadly storm, Jo chases the largest tornado to ever strike Oklahoma as her marriage implodes and rival scientists will stop and nothing to steal her breakthrough

Know Before You Go
You should arrive before 8:30 p.m. to get your spot. Feel free to bring a blanket to sit on; there will be a limited supply of chairs available. Bottled water is permitted, but not glass. Reservations are not taken; space is available on a first-come, first-served basis. All are welcome!

For everyone's safety, we are asking all participants to observe the following guidelines:

  • Please wear a mask if you are unvaccinated, or if it makes you feel more comfortable
  • All individuals should maintain social distancing of six feet during programming, regardless of vaccination status
  • Please wear a mask if social distancing cannot be maintained
  • Wash your hands before attending a program
  • Stay home if you are sick

Glass bottles and alcoholic beverages are strictly prohibited.

Contact (212) 360-1430 or accessibility@parks.nyc.gov for more information regarding accessibility.

Start time: 8:30 pm

End time: 10:30 pm

Contact phone: (718) 667-3545

description:

Join NYC Parks and New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for this free family film!

Coming to America 2

This 2021 long-awaited sequel to the classic Eddie Murphy comedy finds follows Prince Akeem as he become King, discovers he has a long-lost son, and devious enemy on the rise. Eddie Murphy, Arsenio, Hall, John Amos, Shari Headly, Paul Bates and James Earl Jones reprise their roles. Directed by Craig Brewer (Hustle & Flow), this film also stars Wesley Snipes, Leslie Jones, Jermaine Fowler, Kiki Layne, Teyana Taylor and Bella Murphey. Rated PG-13.

title: CANCELLED: Sunset Yoga
description:
Date: September 1, 2021

Please note: this event has been cancelled.

Enjoy free yoga classes while overlooking the beautiful Hudson River and basking in the glow of the setting sun!

Arrive early and bring a towel or a yoga mat and water. Mats must be socially distanced - 6 feet apart. To measure, use your mats!

Capacity is limited due to NY Reopening restrictions. Attendance is on a “first-come, first-served” basis. Class participants must sign an NYC Parks/Fort Tryon Park Trust waiver on-site at each session.

Please note: Abby’s Lawn is slightly sloped and there are some uneven spots. Rain or wet ground cancels the event. Please check the Fort Tryon Park Trust Facebook page.

Certified instructor, Stacey Linden, has been teaching yoga for twenty years and it has been integral in her life — physically, mentally, and spiritually. We are happy to have her share its many facets with our park community. Stacey teaches at all levels and believes yoga should be practiced, not “perfected.” Every time we step onto our mats, we can be just a little surprised by where our bodies, minds, and breath are at that moment.

Sunset Yoga is a program presented by the Fort Tryon Park Trust that takes place from June 2 through September 1.

title: I Was Here: Reshaping the American Commemorative Landscape
description:
Date: September 1, 2021

By Marjorie Guyon, Artist for I Was Here, Marshall Fields, Community Liaison for I Was Here, Patrick J. Mitchell, Photographer for I Was Here, Dr. Michael Preacely, Music Producer/Director for I Was Here, Michael Baer, President and Owner of Fusioncorp and PIVT, Augmented Reality for I Was Here, and Barry Darnell Burton, Ancestor Spirit Portrait model, Installations and Writer for I Was Here.

Created by photographing contemporary African Americans as archetypal Ancestor Spirits, the Portraits invoke the Human Family - Man, Woman, Child, Mother, Father, Sister, Brother. These emblematic Ancestor Spirits Portraits ask us to examine who we are to each other, who we are as a nation and how we can work to heal the wound that enslavement created in our citizenship. The project is a synthesis of history, image, geography, and soundscape creating an opportunity for citizens of all ages to come face to face and heart to heart with a spiritual history rarely, if ever, encountered on the streets of America.

Register online

The War With Grandpa

This hilarious comedy follows a young boy (Oakes Fegley) who fights in a prank war with his grandfather (Robert De Niro) to get his grandfather to move out of his room after he moves in with his family. description:
Date: September 1, 2021

Please note: this event has been cancelled due to inclement weather.

Join us for a watercolor painting workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kalila Adbur-Razzaq will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

About the artist:

Kalila Abdur-Razzaq was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She recently graduated Purchase College with a concentration in painting and a minor in Art History. Her preferred mediums are oil, watercolor, and silkscreen. As of 2021, Abdur-Razzaq is included in three permanent installations. The most recent is a commission by The Colored Girls Museum of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

title: River Project: Diversity Digest
description:
Date: September 1, 2021

During Diversity Digest, you'll learn what it means to be a naturalist, cataloging local wildlife with the free iNaturalist app throughout the week and then sharing your observations with the HRPK community. Together, we'll congratulate those who made the most observations and highlight some of our favorite images. You’ll also get a chance to ask Park staff questions!

HRPK's River Project conducts research and offers hands-on environmental education and scientific programming with the purpose of communicating the ecological importance of the Park’s 400-acre Estuarine Sanctuary. Dedicated to community engagement, stewardship and learning, the River Project offers at-home STEM activities, tours of marine-biology stations and other educational resources to support scientific understanding of the Lower Hudson Estuary.

Join us on Facebook live @HudsonRiverPark. If you are a teacher or educator and would like to have your class join via Zoom, please contact education@hrpt.ny.gov.

title: River Project: Live From the Field
description:
Date: September 2, 2021

Wildlife thrives all over NYC, especially in HRPK's waters! Tune into @HudsonRiverPark's Instagram Live for an insider’s look into the Park's Estuarine Sanctuary as we study environmental DNA, analyze microplastics, sample fish populations and so much more!

HRPK's River Project conducts research and offers hands-on environmental education and scientific programming with the purpose of communicating the ecological importance of the Park’s 400-acre Estuarine Sanctuary. Dedicated to community engagement, stewardship and learning, the River Project offers at-home STEM activities, tours of marine-biology stations and other educational resources to support scientific understanding of the Lower Hudson Estuary.

description:

Dwight Brewster aka Dr. Mambo is a musician, producer, arranger, songwriter, on-air personality, music publisher, and technology guru. A skilled pianist, he is especially accomplished in Latin music, having produced for Fania Records in its early days, including on Willie's Colon's earliest recordings as a leader. He has appeared on dozens of recordings since then while earning the respect of his peers in jazz and Latin styles

description:

Join NYC Parks and New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for this free film!

Dirty Dancing (1987)

This classic summer romance follows Baby (Jennifer Grey) as she spends a summer at a resort in the Catskills with her family, against her will. But, when the resort's dance instructor, Johnny (Patrick Swayze), enlists Baby as his new partner, and the two fall in love and have a magical summer despite Baby's father’s disapproval. title: Movies Under the Stars at Corporal Thompson Park: Mortal Kombat (2021)
description:
Date: September 2, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film.

In “Mortal Kombat,” MMA fighter Cole Young, accustomed to taking a beating for money, is unaware of his heritage—or why Outworld's Emperor Shang Tsung has sent his best warrior, Sub-Zero, an otherworldly Cryomancer, to hunt Cole down. Fearing for his family's safety, Cole goes in search of Sonya Blade at the direction of Jax, a Special Forces Major who bears the same strange dragon marking Cole was born with. Soon, he finds himself at the temple of Lord Raiden, an Elder God and the protector of Earthrealm, who grants sanctuary to those who bear the mark. Here, Cole trains with experienced warriors Liu Kang, Kung Lao, and rogue mercenary Kano, as he prepares to stand with Earth’s greatest champions against the enemies of Outworld in a high stakes battle for the universe. But will Cole be pushed hard enough to unlock his arcana—the immense power from within his soul—in time to save not only his family, but to stop Outworld once and for all? Rated R.

Know Before You Go
You should arrive before 8:00 p.m. to get your spot. Feel free to bring a blanket to sit on; there will be a limited supply of chairs available. Bottled water is permitted, but not glass. Reservations are not taken; space is available on a first-come, first-served basis. All are welcome!

description:

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs. Movies begin at dusk. You should arrive before 7:45 p.m. to get your spot. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited. Reservations are not taken.

Fast forward to the 1980s as Wonder Woman’s next big screen adventure finds her facing two all-new foes: Max Lord and The Cheetah. With director Patty Jenkins back at the helm and Gal Gadot returning in the title role, “Wonder Woman 1984” is Warner Bros. Pictures’ follow up to the DC Super Hero’s first outing, 2017’s record-breaking “Wonder Woman,” which took in $822 million at the worldwide box office. The film also stars Chris Pine as Steve Trevor, Kristen Wiig as The Cheetah, Pedro Pascal as Max Lord, Robin Wright as Antiope, and Connie Nielsen as Hippolyta. Rated PG-13.

title: Arts, Culture & Fun: Watercolor Painting Workshop
description:
Date: September 3, 2021

Join us for a watercolor painting workshop series in partnership with Seeds of the League. Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

About the artist:

Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

Registration
Please register at Cathy.mitchell@parks.nyc.gov.

title: Dom Salvador Samba Jazz Sextet / Screening: Dom Salvador & Abolition / DJ Nyack & Eduardo Brechó
description:
Date: September 4, 2021

In Association with 25th Inffinito Brazilian Film Festival

Tickets are no longer required for free performances at SummerStage. All free performances will be open to the public, first come, first served, with limited capacity, and will continue to follow CDC recommendations. Visit here for more information.

SCHEDULE

5 PM – Doors

6 PM – Rooftop Films Summer Series Films (see below)

7 PM – Screening of “Dom Salvador & Abolition” (see below)

8:30 PM – Performance by The Dom Salvador Samba Jazz Sextet

This performance will be livestreamed on SummerStageAnywhere.org.

—

This double bill honors an Afro-Brazilian legend with the premiere of a film documentary screening that explores his legacy and a live performance that celebrates it. Often called the “godfather of Brazilian soul,” Dom Salvador is a jazz pianist, composer, and arranger who helped create Bossa Nova before fleeing Brazil at the height of its military dictatorship. Dom Salvador & Abolition follows him through his adopted hometown of New York City—where’s been the resident pianist at the River Café for the last 44 years—flitting from record shops to jazz clubs to the hallowed stage at Carnegie Hall. He brings his Samba Jazz Sextet to his performance at SummerStage, featuring Kamau M. Adilifu (trumpet), Laura Dreyer (saxophone, flute), Gili Lopes (bass), Alevtina Wilcox (trombone), Graciliano Zambonin (drums), and featuring guest vocalist Raquel Lima.

--

About "Dom Salvador & Abolition"

An immersive journey, “Dom Salvador and Abolition” is the untold story of Dom Salvador, an Afro-Brazilian musician who found a home in New York. Departing at the height of Brazil’s military dictatorship in 73’, Salvador left behind an enormous shadow.

title: Fort Tryon Rocks! Geology Hike
description:

New York City is the site of ancient earth-shaking and earth-shaping events. The bedrock that anchors the city’s skyscrapers tells a story of a place going back more than a billion years. The island of Manhattan is built on three strata known as Manhattan Schist, Inwood Marble, and Fordham Gneiss.

Join our Urban Park Rangers on this hike and learn about why Manhattan rocks!

title: Sunset Yoga
description:
Date: September 8, 2021

Enjoy free yoga classes while overlooking the beautiful Hudson River and basking in the glow of the setting sun!

Arrive early and bring a towel or a yoga mat and water. Mats must be socially distanced - 6 feet apart. To measure, use your mats!

Capacity is limited due to NY Reopening restrictions. Attendance is on a “first-come, first-served” basis. Class participants must sign an NYC Parks/Fort Tryon Park Trust waiver on-site at each session.

Please note: Abby’s Lawn is slightly sloped and there are some uneven spots. Rain or wet ground cancels the event. Please check the Fort Tryon Park Trust Facebook page.

Certified instructor, Stacey Linden, has been teaching yoga for twenty years and it has been integral in her life — physically, mentally, and spiritually. We are happy to have her share its many facets with our park community. Stacey teaches at all levels and believes yoga should be practiced, not “perfected.” Every time we step onto our mats, we can be just a little surprised by where our bodies, minds, and breath are at that moment.

Sunset Yoga is a program presented by the Fort Tryon Park Trust that takes place from June 2 through September 1.

title: Markers on the Land: Slavery, Commemoration and the History of Africans in Northern Manhattan
description:
Date: September 8, 2021

By Dr. Robert W. Snyder, Manhattan Borough Historian and Professor Emeritus of American Studies and Journalism, Rutgers University-Newark, Peggy King Jorde, Cultural Projects Consultant and Global expert, Dr. Andrea Mosterman, Associate Professor in History at the University of New Orleans, and Richard Tomczak, Professor and Proposal Development Coordinator at Stony Brook University.

With changes contemplated for an African burial ground and Native American ritual site in Inwood, join us for a panel discussion on the history of slavery at the Dyckman Farmhouse, in New Amsterdam, and in the early years of the United States. How might we best study this past and commemorate it in the present?

Register online

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

About the artist:

Kalila Abdur-Razzaq was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She recently graduated Purchase College with a concentration in painting and a minor in Art History. Her preferred mediums are oil, watercolor, and silkscreen. As of 2021, Abdur-Razzaq is included in three permanent installations. The most recent is a commission by The Colored Girls Museum of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

title: River Project: Ask a Scientist
description:
Date: September 8, 2021

During Ask a Scientist, engage with real scientists in real time and explore current park research with a local STEM expert followed by a live Q&A session. Dive into a fascinating science topic each month, including fish ecology, marine plastics and diversity and inclusion in STEM, while asking the scientists your burning questions!

HRPK's River Project conducts research and offers hands-on environmental education and scientific programming with the purpose of communicating the ecological importance of the Park’s 400-acre Estuarine Sanctuary. Dedicated to community engagement, stewardship and learning, the River Project offers at-home STEM activities, tours of marine-biology stations and other educational resources to support scientific understanding of the Lower Hudson Estuary.

Be prepared to walk approximately 2 miles. Proper footwear required.

- All vsitors and staff must wear a mask during the entire event.

- All equipment/supplies used will be sanitized before and after the event.

HRPK's River Project conducts research and offers hands-on environmental education and scientific programming with the purpose of communicating the ecological importance of the Park’s 400-acre Estuarine Sanctuary. title: Bread & Puppet Theater: Our Domestic Resurrection Circus
description:
Date: September 10, 2021

Bread and Puppet Theater comes to The Old Stone House with a brand new performance in the tradition of the Circuses that began at Goddard College in Plainfield, Vermont in 1970.

Traditional circus tropes are reinterpreted with the help of Bread and Puppet’s distinctive folk iconography to draw attention to the urgent issues of the day. Stilt dancers, paper maché beasts of all sizes, and a Bread and Puppet’s Fight-Against-The-End-Of-The-World Brass Band contribute their riotous inspiration to this colorful spectacle of protest and celebration.

After the show, Bread and Puppet will serve its famous sourdough rye bread with aioli, and Bread and Puppet’s “Cheap Art” – books, posters, postcards, pamphlets, and banners from the Bread & Puppet Press – will be for sale.

Show Length: Approximately 1 hour.

Get your tickets here, no one turned away for lack of funds.

title: NRPA Parks For Pollinator Bioblitz @Freshkills Park
description:
Date: September 10, 2021

Participate in the NRPA Parks for Pollinator Blitz with Freshkills Park Staff at Freshkills Park. Help support community science, and taking part is easy!

Lace-up your shoes for a nature walk at Freshkills Park. Freshkills Park researchers will take you behind the scenes to visit areas that are currently closed to the public. On this one-mile walk, you’ll use iNaturalist to share and identify the different pollinators and plants found in the grasslands at Freshkills Park.

Parks for Pollinators is a national campaign to raise awareness and community involvement in the pollinator crisis through local parks and recreation and like-minded organizations. NRPA and The Scotts Miracle-Gro Foundation are challenging local parks to get involved and host a pollinator BioBlitz during September.

Join the Freshkills Park Project on iNaturalist to submit your observations all September, be sure to stop by Schmul Park, Owl Hollow Soccer Fields, and the New Springville Greenway to participate on your own time.

This program is designed for ages 6+.

Register online

Transportation: By registering for this event, you confirm you will provide your own transportation. Each ticket admits 1 car, containing up to 5 participants. During registration, you will be asked about additional participants in your car.

Gear: Wear a hat and sturdy shoes that you don’t mind getting wet or muddy. Please also bring water, a snack, and sunblock.

Technology: Feel free to take photos, but consider carefully before bringing any electronic devices with you as they may possibly get wet, damaged, or dropped during the program.

Restrictions: You will be asked to sign an activity waiver before participating in the program.

Cancellation: This tour will be canceled if registration is too low, or if there is a 60% or greater chance of rain on the day of the event. You will be asked to confirm your registration by email before the tour. As we receive cancellations, names will be added from the waitlist. If you know you will be unable to attend, please cancel your registration by emailing info@freshkillspark.org so we can fill the reservation.

Students who participate and report observations with Freshkills Park Staff can receive community service credit.

COVID-19 Precautions:

You will find current information on NYC Parks safety guidelines here.

Masks, gloves, and hand sanitizer will be available.

By participating in this event you are acknowledging that you and your guests have not experienced a fever, not tested positive for COVID-19, and have not been exposed to anyone with COVID-19 within 14 days of the event. Should you develop symptoms after registration, please cancel your registration by emailing info@freshkillspark.org.

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (929) 481-2795

Location: Freshkills Park Event Entrance

Kumandra is a place where humans and dragons peacefully coexist. When sinister monsters called the Druun threaten the community, however, the dragons readily make a sacrifice to save the human race. description:

The tours are split into two parts, with two A/B pairs this summer and one in the coming fall. Put on your walking shoes—each part is approximately 1.5 miles long! Tour A begins at the 72nd Street park entrance and proceeds north to the West 94th Street Joan of Arc statue. Tour B begins at the 122nd Street General Grant National Memorial and proceeds south to the West 100th Street Fireman’s Memorial. Space is limited, and registration is required.

title: Second Saturdays Trailwork Party + Bike Share at Highbridge Bike Park
description:
Date: September 11, 2021

Dig, then ride with us on NYCMTB's monthly welcome days at Highbridge Park in Manhattan!

Bring your friends and family for a day of fun in the woods and learn what it takes to build, maintain, and ride the most progressive urban bike park in America! There will be light trail maintenance tasks for all ages from 10:00 a.m. to noon. All participants, NYCMTB members, or anyone with logged volunteer hours, receive a free 20-minute clinic and a guided ride throughout the trails from 12:30 p.m to 3:00 p.m. Bikes and helmets provided!

Highbridge Park is the home of NYC's first Mountain Biking Course. The 3-mile course offers trails of varying difficulty from intermediate to expert and a free-ride trail that includes drops, steeps, and berms. The park also features a dirt jump park and pump track, making it a good place to develop different skills at all levels. The course has been featured in national media and is stewarded by volunteers just like you!

Make this day your introduction to the park, or to the sport of off-road cycling. Interested volunteers are encouraged to participate regardless of age, ability or gender. There is something for everyone at Highbridge - It's NYC's bike park!

Please bring water, sunscreen, bug repellant, and sturdy shoes or boots.

Register on Eventbrite at nycmtb.eventbrite.com.

Registration: By registering for this event, you confirm you will provide your own transportation. When registering on Eventbrite, select the Freshkills Park Alliance project.

Gear: Wear clothes you don't mind getting dirty, long pants are preferred. Closed-toed shoes like sneakers or boots are required. Please also bring water and sunblock. Gardening gloves will be provided.

Restrictions: You will be asked to sign an activity waiver before participating in the program. Participants must be Ages 14+. Participants under 18 will require a parent or guardian's signature. Waivers will be emailed with confirmation emails closer to the event.

Cancellation: This event will be canceled if registration is too low, or if there is a 60% or greater chance of rain on the day of the event. You will be asked to confirm your registration by email before the event. As we receive cancellations, names will be added from the waitlist. If you know you will be unable to attend, please cancel your registration by emailing info@freshkillspark.org so we can fill the reservation.

This event will follow the current NYC Parks safety guidelines, which can be found here.

description:

Artist Kenneth Fitzpatrick will teach you how to draw and paint using nature as your inspiration. Learn about light, color, and design while making art en plein air (outside). All levels from beginners to advanced are welcome.

For your comfort, bring a mat, blanket, or folding chair to sit on. Feel free to bring your own watercolors, paper, water, and brushes. Limited supplies will be provided as well.

About the artist:

Kenneth Fitzpatrick, a graduate of the High School of Art & Design, was born and raised in New York City. His awards include P.S. Art, a citywide competition for pre-K to 12, culminating in an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a Seeds of the League Scholarship. Ken’s work focuses on compositional storytelling using the mediums of oils, graphite, watercolors, tattoos, and digital art. His goals include finishing his degree in game development and encouraging others to pursue their art.

Seeds of the League is the Art Students League's community program.

title: Movies Under the Stars at O'Donohue Park: Man on Wire
description:
Date: September 11, 2021

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs. Movies begin at dusk. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited.

On August 7, 1974, a 23-year-old Frenchman took the whole world by surprise when he walked on a thin wire strung between the Twin Towers, over 400 meters above the ground. Philippe Petit had been dreaming about the towers for six years and had spent eight months in New York planning the masterstroke. With the help of friends and other collaborators, Petit was able to get around the security of the World Trade Center, bringing inside the heavy steel wire as well as all the necessary equipment for the exploit, and stringing the wire across the two towers. Oscar® winner for best documentary in 2009, James Marsh's film narrates an extraordinary adventure featuring the testimony of the protagonist, the young tightrope walker who surprised the world with his high-wire walk across New York's twin towers, delivering an unparalleled, unique show that became known as the artistic crime of the century. Rated PG-13.

title: CANCELLED: Movies Under the Stars: The Sun Is Also a Star
description:
Date: September 11, 2021

Please note: this event has been cancelled.

Join NYC Parks and the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment for a free film!

College-bound romantic Daniel Bae and Jamaica-born pragmatist Natasha Kingsley meet—and fall for each other—over one magical day amidst the fervor and flurry of New York City. Sparks immediately fly between these two strangers, who might never have met had fate not given them a little push. But will fate be enough to take these teens from star-crossed to lucky in love? With just hours left on the clock in what looks to be her last day in the U.S., Natasha is fighting against her family’s deportation as fiercely as she’s fighting her budding feelings for Daniel, who is working just as hard to convince her they are destined to be together. Rated PG-13.

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs. Movies begin at dusk. You should arrive before 7:30 p.m. to get your spot. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited. Reservations are not taken.

title: 'Land Markings' Exhibition Opening
description:
Date: September 12, 2021

Due to weather, the opening reception of our latest contemporary art exhibition, Land Markings has been rescheduled to September 12. The exhibition will be on view on Fridays through Sundays from noon to 3:00 p.m. from August 27 - October 10.

Join us in the Great Room for the opening reception of our latest contemporary art exhibition, Land Markings.

Curated by Katherine Gressel and RedMoon Arts, Inc., Land Markings brings together four New York-based artists of Indigenous heritage: Jeremy Dennis, Dennis RedMoon Darkeem, Ella Mahoney, and Natasha Smoke Santiago, who have created works commenting on the past, present, and future of land use in the areas surrounding Old Stone House

Their work explores such topics as the acknowledgment and preservation of local Indigenous cultural sites in Brooklyn and New York State; under-recognized histories of local trade and land transfer; and land use issues facing contemporary Indigenous and other BIPOC communities.

A central theme in all the work is the importance of recognizing the continued presence and influence of Indigenous communities in the New York area, and the seizure of colonized land from its original inhabitants. Yet the work also suggests the limitations of mere acknowledgment, in some cases proposing or supporting models of indigenous sovereignty and sustainability that defy a singular narrative or type of mark-making. Many of the works on view combine traditional craft with contemporary art practices, while rejecting cultural assimilation and asserting the importance of craft, performance, and storytelling in maintaining ties to land and community and as a form of activism.

Much of the art is site-specific and created for this exhibition, including Jeremy Dennis’ photos and map of culturally significant Native American sites in Brooklyn; Dennis RedMoon Darkeem’s interactive gumball machine featuring trade items found on OSH land in the 1600s; Natasha Smoke Santiago’s ceramic tile made in the Iroquois pottery tradition documenting local trade history; and Ella Mahoney’s outdoor banners that draw from her Aquinnah Wampanoag background to imagine a decolonized future for the Gowanus neighborhood of Brooklyn.

Land Markings precedes the upcoming redesign of the Old Stone House’s permanent exhibit to include its Lenape history. Today, despite the displacement of its original Lenape residents, New York City still has one of the largest intertribal indigenous communities in the country. Land Markings is the first in a series of exhibits and programs at OSH that will provide opportunities for contemporary Indigenous artists to connect a greater awareness of the past to critical conversations about Brooklyn’s future, including fair and sustainable uses of our natural and built environment.

Location: Old Stone House (in J.J. Byrne Playground)

title: Summer on the Hudson: Monuments Tour of Riverside Park
description:
Date: September 12, 2021

The New-York Historical Society and Summer on the Hudson are partnering for a Monuments of Riverside Park Walking Tour through one of New York City’s Scenic Landmarks. Join us for a guided walk along Riverside Drive that highlights the park’s development as well as its historic monuments.

The tours are split into two parts, with two A/B pairs this summer and one in the coming fall. Put on your walking shoes—each part is approximately 1.5 miles long! Tour A begins at the 72nd Street park entrance and proceeds north to the West 94th Street Joan of Arc statue. Tour B begins at the 122nd Street General Grant National Memorial and proceeds south to the West 100th Street Fireman’s Memorial. Space is limited, and registration is required.

  • Tour A: Saturday, September 11 | 10:30 am to 12 pm
  • Tour B: Sunday, September 12 | 10:30 am to 12 pm

description:
